The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race.
"Introduction", paragraph 1
The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine.

Half-Life. Such a amazing masterpiece by Valve. In today's state of gaming with new consoles, hardware, etc. Half-Life one is still, still! Not outdated, it may seem like it, but for right now, it's an amazing game I recommend you playing! For the graphics, they're still decent for today, even though Half-Life 2 is a entire upgrade for graphics. As the story of Half-Life. You're playing as a typical male figure "Gordon Freeman." Trying to survive and escape his way out of Black Mesa. The story may-be short, boring, or not even worth your time! But! The gameplay is the main reason why I still play Half-Life one. Like always, always remember..

Run.               Think.           Shoot.                Live.

Quite honestly, this was one of the most enjoyable experiences that I've had with a video game. I'm new to gaming, and being stubborn and an overachiever at times, I decided that beginning this game on hard difficulty was the way to go. That was a regrettable decision. Nevertheless, the game was still immensely fun. 

The story itself is not particularly deep, but the seemingly deliberate ambiguity of the plot left me thinking. With regards to the gameplay, I have no major complaints; in fact, the only objections I might have are sticking in place while turning valves in-game (which is rather sad for the "Valve" game development company) and having trouble climbing ladders, but otherwise I never had a bug. The graphics are not top-of-the-line, of course, but that said, the environment still feels real and immersive; the lighting in this game is particularly good. All in all, I'd happily recommend this game to whoever wants to start gaming with the classics: it's fun, fast, and still pulls its weight after twenty three years. Good job, Valve! I look forward to trying your sequel.
Great game! deserves its classic status. both expansion packs are fun too!

Despite being clunky, having soo many loading screens, and having rather dated graphics, this game is still a blast to play through! Being a relative noob to PC, I just finished my first playthrough of Half-Life. I usually play on medium difficulty but even so this classic proved challenging especially in Xen. The aforementioned problems with the game don't take away too much from the game other than being frustrating on occasion, but usually rather add a little charm to let you know that this is a pretty old game. I thought that the story was enjoyable and did a great job of environmental and spoken storytelling. The weapon and enemy variation ensured that there was never a dull moment. The puzzles were generally fun and the overall gameplay had enough variation throughout the different levels that kept things fresh. The soundtrack provided a brilliant atmosphere when trying to make the air uneasy or make the action intense. In conclusion, I think that the fact that most components of this game still stand the test of time is reason enough to give it a playthrough for its low price.

I fucking love this game, I can go to it countless times and still find something new not to mention the different expansions and deathmatch. It's a fun test of skill and brains in some cases, you really are forced to adapt and stratergise with the weapons you have. Very fun and rewarding experience

This game has a great story.

Half-Life is an amazing title in many ways. Not only has it been influential to gaming as a whole but it made developers and players rethink how stories in that kind of media could be told. Half-Life plays into gaming's biggest strength, being interactive. Everything experienced in the game is first hand, it doesn't make you feel like your playing as someone, it makes you feel like you are that someone. Gordon Freeman is silent allowing for the player to think on their own and discover the story for themselves as it pieces together. It makes this game immersive in a way that even in present day, I hadn't experienced before. Every bit and piece of the story is seen and experienced by you first hand, no third person dialogue, or even cutscenes. This game tells a compelling story of a scientist who's experiment has gone terribly wrong and is now just trying to escape Black Mesa Research Facility with his life. The story is full of mysteriousness and twists and it's something that any gamer must play at least once in their life. The gunplay is extremely fun and holds up still today even when compared to modern day shooters. It amazes me how I became so attached to a silent protagonist but yet I did,  and after I finished the game I was ready to start it all over again. Half-Life spawned many games like Counter Strike and for that I am very thankful, as Counter Strike is one of my favorite games. The multiplayer in this game as well is so much fun, especially with some friends. It is replayable and addicting and I would definitely recommend it. The only real fault in this game for me is the final stage on the alien homeworld Xen. This stage felt rushed and lacked content. I really wish they had put just a little more effort into Xen, as that would just be the cherry on top. Other than that however, Half-Life in my opinion is one of the greatest gaming masterpieces of all time. I give it a 9.5/10

Half-Life, le jeu le plus marquant de l'ann√©e 1998 et qui aura v√©ritablement marqu√© un tournant dans le genre des jeux de tir √† la premi√®re personne.
C'est aussi un des seuls jeux dont les articles promotionnels de l'√©poque m'auront pouss√© √† me pr√©cipiter en magasin pour me le procurer.
Premier changement par rapport aux autres jeux du genre : aucune sc√®ne cin√©matique pour introduire, entrecouper ou cl√¥turer les diff√©rents chapitres. Le jeu se joue en continu, ce qui renforce l'immersion.
Second changement : les dialogues avec les personnages non joueurs, qui rendent le jeu plus vivant.
Troisi√®me changement : l'IA des ennemis humains qui tranche nettement avec ce qui se faisait √† l'√©poque. Elle aura laiss√© une empreinte durable dans la m√©moire des joueurs.
Quatri√®me changement : la trame sc√©naristique, Half-Life raconte une histoire, et m√™me si ce point n'aura eu de cesse de faire d√©bat depuis, c'est pourtant bien le cas.
Aujourd'hui le jeu accuse le poids des ann√©es, que ce soit sur le plan technique et sur le plan graphique. Pour qui ne l'a pas connu √† l'√©poque, il sera peut-√™tre difficile de le conseiller, m√™me s'il constitue une pierre angulaire du genre √† laquelle les joueurs et les studios de d√©veloppement auront rendu de nombreux hommages.
Des ann√©es apr√®s le lancement de Steam, j'ai moi-m√™me continu√© d'y jouer mais dans sa version CD-ROM originale. Depuis l'arriv√©e de son remake, Black Mesa Source, j'avoue que c'est lui qui a ma pr√©f√©rence et que je conseillerais.
Toutefois je ne m'interdis pas de temps √† autres de jouer √† Half-Life dans sa version d'origine, √† la faveur de mods, qu'ils soient d'√©poque ou non : USS Darkstar, Adam, Poke 646, Azure Sheep ou encore les trilogies They Hunger, Timeline... Et j'ai d√©finitivement mis de c√¥t√© la version CD-ROM originale pour me concentrer sur la version Steam.
